Objet: Fondation d'un établissement américain pour la récolte du caoutchouc, de l'ivoire et autres produits du sol.-
Boma, le 16 Mars 1908.-
Monsieur le Secrétaire d'Etat,

J'ai l'honneur de vous faire parvenir, sous ce pli, la copie d'une lettre du 24 Février dernier, par laquelle le Consul Général des Etats Unis d'Amerique m'a posé diverses questions au sujet du régime applicable à une maison de commerce américaine qui voudrait s'établir au Congo pour trafiquer le caoutchouc, l'ivoire, le copal et les autres produits du sol, avec les indigènes.
Vous trouverez également, ci joint, la copie de la réponse que j'ai adressée au Consul Général.
Le Vice Gouverneur Général,
American Consular Service
Boma, February 24, 1908
Monsieur le Gouverneur Général,

Being désirous of obtaining further information as to trade conditions in the Kongo Free State, I have the honor to request of your Excellency a reply at as early a date as possible to the following questions. It is not intended that the region known as the Lower Kongo is to be included in the point upon which I desire information.

1. Under that conditions would the Kongo Free State permit an American commercial house of financial responsibility to establish itself in the Kalai district, or in any other district now exploited by Concessionary companies or by the State "en regie" for the purpose of buying rubber, ivory and gum copal and all other products of the soil from the natives.

2. Will the State sell sufficient land in suitable in the above districts to an American commercial house to permit of the érection of factories and warehouses in order to enable it to carry on a trade with the natives in the above products? If so under what conditions?

3. If not, in what districts in the territory of the State may an American commercial house which has no concession of land, buy sufficient land and factories and warehouses and trade freely in all produce of the soil including ivory direct with the natives and what formalities must be gone through with to enable
it to do so.

4. Will the State allow our American Company to operate steamers on the upper Congo and all its affluents for the transportation of goods belonging to third parties and of passengers both white and black? If so under what conditions

5. Will it sell enough land and at Lés or in the vicinity along the navigable waterway for the érection of repair shops, docks and yards for the building of steamers to carry on a regular transport business.

Smith
Consul General

Independent State of the Congo
Local Government
Direction
No 661
2 Annexes
Subject: Foundation of an American establishment for the harvest of rubber, ivory, and other products from the ground.-
Boma, March 16, 1908.
Mr. Secretary of State

I have the honor transmit to you herewith, the copy of the letter from last February 24, by which the Consulate General of the United States of America posed various questions to me about the practical diet for an American trading firm that wants to establish itself in the Congo for trafficking rubber, ivory, copal, and other products from the soil, with the natives.
You will also find, attached here, the copy of the response that I addressed to the Consulate General.
The Vice Governor General,
